entry.title: Astro Bot review - a shot of pure fun and PlayStation nostalgia

link.title: Astro Bot review - a shot of pure fun and PlayStation nostalgia

entry.summary: A lot of the weirdness in modern gaming comes from critics and consumers who are overly concerned with the business side of the industry, focused on sales figures, profitability, and competition between manufacturers rather than the quality of the games they play. It‚Äôs an odd predicament ‚Äì perhaps unique to video games ‚Äì and it‚Äôs one that Astro Bot blasts straight through. When you play this game, it‚Äôs impossible to think about anything except what‚Äôs on the screen. Astro Bot is a pure shot of fun and nostalgia from start to finish Much of that is due to the game‚Äôs retro simplicity ‚Äì not in terms of difficulty, but in the premise and core gameplay: Astro Bot is on a level. He must get from Point A to Point B. There are obstacles in his way, either enemies or physical hurdles. You must find a way to overcome them, and have fun doing so. That‚Äôs it. There‚Äôs no grand narrative here. No jarring commentary on real-world issues, or mechanics that make you sigh and yearn for what gaming once was. The only time my mind drifted from the level before my eyes was to consider the choices behind its design, and my conclusion was usually something like: ‚ÄúThe person at Team Asobi who made this really knows how to make a fun game!‚Äù Hopping through the galaxy The beauty of Astro Bot‚Äôs story is that it barely has one. 300 bots are riding in a spaceship shaped like a PlayStation 5 when it is attacked by an alien. It explodes, its parts and the bots scattered across the galaxy. The alien steals the CPU, and Astro Bot blasts off on his controller mini-ship to find the parts and his friends. There is one level per planet, with planets divided into star systems, each capped with a final boss and a stage themed around a beloved PlayStation game. Even exploring the galaxy map is a lot of fun, with secret levels to uncover and ships carrying collectables to chase. I couldn‚Äôt help but compare it to the expansive but much more sterile and borderline indecipherable map in Starfield. Far from glorified menus, even the star system screens have their secrets to uncover Each level has a handful of bots to save ‚Äì some generic, some dressed up as characters from PlayStation history. When Astro finds them, they‚Äôre stowed inside his controller ship, and at the end of the level they‚Äôre sent back to the planet the ship crashed on, where the PS5 mothership‚Äôs carcass serves as the centrepiece of a museum full of all the bots you‚Äôve discovered and rescued to date. The other main collectable is jigsaw puzzle pieces. While Astro‚Äôs Playroom used these to construct a pretty mural, Astro Bot gives them a much more practical application. Completing a smaller puzzle unlocks new functionality at the crash site ‚Äì a hub to change outfits or give your ship a lick of paint, for example. Two-button challenge Astro Bot‚Äôs gameplay is just as simple: he can run, jump, use boosters in his feet, and hit enemies. Don‚Äôt let that fool you ‚Äì there‚Äôs some challenging platforming to be found, both in the main levels towards the end of the game, but especially in unlockable gauntlet stages themed around the PlayStation symbols (you‚Äôll be very thankful that your PS5‚Äôs SSD allows near-instant reloads upon death). While one mistake is usually enough to kill Astro, checkpoints are so frequent that you only ever lose a few seconds of progress. I was grateful for this as a way of reducing the risk when trying out a new mechanic or attempting an ambitious manoeuvre to reach some distant platform in search of treasure ‚Äì vital in a game with so many secret areas and obscurely located bots to be rescued. Special abilities - like becoming a giant sponge - add variety across levels Many levels have a special upgrade, giving Astro a booster pack, an extended punch reach, or climbing abilities, for example. My favourites were a mod that enabled him to contract into a rolling ball a la Marble Blast, and a very creative stage that transformed him into a sponge, growing larger as he absorbed water. The levels themselves also have creative ideas that add variety and sometimes completely change the premise midway through ‚Äì an ability that shrinks Astro to the size of a mouse and unlocks access to a miniscule level-within-a-level, for example, or an Arabian village level that morphs into a sandstorm hellscape once the player lets a genie out of his lamp to wreak chaos across the area. Retro futurism To me, Astro Bot is what I dreamt gaming might look like when I was playing back in the 1990s. Sure, I expected graphics to improve, but I also thought that the ideas would expand with them. Instead, we got technically sophisticated titles that look great but play like semi-interactive films (especially on PlayStation). Astro Bot might not look as lifelike as The Last of Us or God of War, but it is very crisp and smooth, which is important in a platformer. Where it really shines, though, is in its visual variety ‚Äì there are grassy levels, snowy levels, underwater levels, spooky levels, retro Minecraft-esque levels where everything is made of tiny blocks‚Ä¶ My favourite was an art deco casino stage that felt very Cuphead, complete with evil anthropomorphic cards throwing the rest of the deck at you. Slo-Mo Casino is so colourful and stylish that it was hard to choose just one screenshot Many games have themed sections, but Astro Bot‚Äôs attention to detail sets it apart. Sometimes it‚Äôs in the animation ‚Äì for example, the way Astro skates and twirls along icy surfaces. Sometimes it‚Äôs the enemies, who are given accessories and abilities to match the level‚Äôs theme. And sometimes it‚Äôs the sheer number of objects on the screen ‚Äì each gem, leaf, or gold nugget is a separate item with full physics, and the game revels in letting you smash through full piles of them. All of this is also extremely tactile. Astro Bot was built for the PS5‚Äôs controller, and makes better use of it than any other game I‚Äôve played (edging out Gran Turismo 7, which does a solid job). You can sense each individual object and surface through its vibration, lending the world a very physical feel ‚Äì especially in levels where Astro is curled up in a ball, rolling over panels adorned with spikes. Fun above all else While getting from A to B is the name of the game, Team Asobi has excelled at adding unique attractions for the player to investigate. These are usually clearly signposted, and whenever you find yourself asking ‚ÄúCan I do X?‚Äù, the answer is a resounding yes, rewarded by coins. Can I kick that football into the goal? Sure. Can I jump through the hoop with those dolphins? You bet ‚Äì here‚Äôs your prize. Another favourite moment occurred on a snowy level, where I encountered two penguins building the base of a snowman. To my delight, Astro Bot was able to nudge the ball around the area and collect snow from the ground until he‚Äôd built a snowball bigger than himself. These might sound like inconsequential details, but they demonstrate how the developer prioritised fun above all else. Piles of objects like this are fully interactive - you can wade or smash through as you wish One more variation on the genre comes in those setups involving large numbers of objects and space to play with the physics. I mentioned that sometimes this means Astro wading through chest-high pits of items, but it can also be a pile of inflatables stacked precariously at the top of a water slide, or opening a compartment that dumps a squirrel‚Äôs entire store of acorns on Astro‚Äôs head. The fun continues on the crash planet, where certain areas and activities require tens, or even hundreds, of your rescued bots to chip in to lift heavy objects or form human ladders. It‚Äôs cute to see usually hostile faces like Psycho Mantis contribute to the effort, and some stunts and animations are wacky in and of themselves. If you‚Äôve never seen 60 bots swing a pig by the tail, you haven‚Äôt lived. Branded brethren Aside from the gameplay, one of the most notable things about Astro Bot is how closely it is tied to the PlayStation brand. The objective of the entire game is to reconstruct a giant PS5, of course, and the novelty for many players will come from collecting characters and unlocking their trademark items and scenes ‚Äì even if, classily, those individuals and their games are never directly named. That‚Äôs nice, but the more surprising nostalgia for me came from smaller details in the levels. The coins Astro collects (which always reminded me of chocolate coins) are stamped with the PlayStation logo. The save slots are PS1 memory cards. Some ropes and wires are PS1 controller extension cables, complete with chunky connectors. And ‚Äì perhaps my giddiest discovery ‚Äì even the raindrops in the spooky levels form the controller button symbols when they hit the ground. PlayStation symbology is often subtly woven into levels - like these triangle mushrooms PlayStation branding is often very plain. Its logo and trademarks are increasingly minimalist, and as the generations have gone on any remaining colour has been sucked out. Even the symbols on the PS5 controller are grey, abandoning their signature hues. Sony has little of the fun and vibrance of a brand like Nintendo. But when you take all those icons, restore their colour, and place them amid the bright, cutesy vibe of Astro Bot, it‚Äôs amazing what a difference it makes. This is the first time in years ‚Äì perhaps decades ‚Äì that the PlayStation brand has sparked any kind of wonder in me, and at times the throwbacks triggered the shot of adrenaline I used to enjoy watching that PS1 boot screen as a kid. Generational talent I wouldn‚Äôt want every game to be Astro Bot. There is room for more serious titles that try to look realistic and tackle impactful themes. But I would like more games to be like Astro Bot. Unless you have a Nintendo console or the stomach for sub-par kids‚Äô games, it‚Äôs very rare for a game to be such all-out fun. It‚Äôs a refreshing way to switch off and focus entirely on gameplay, like I did 25 years ago. But Astro Bot took roughly 15 hours to play every level from start to finish. I‚Äôm not complaining about that ‚Äì its RRP is lower than most games and I‚Äôd rather play a concise game of consistent quality than an endless collectathon ‚Äì but it does mean that it‚Äôs too long to run on vibes alone. The gameplay has to match. Astro Bot's immense polish is likely a result of its deliberately constrained scope Team Asobi has delivered near-flawlessly in that department. Astro Bot‚Äôs controls are natural, consistent, and responsive ‚Äì everything you need in a platformer where a split-second jump can have huge stakes ‚Äì and the controller feedback elevates the experience to joyful levels. The controls are solid enough to support not only the casual explore-and-progress levels, but also the more challenging gauntlets that present one threat after another with zero thinking time. So the game plays well. It does things with the PS5 controller that no other game has. The graphics, while simple and bright, are crisp and polished. It‚Äôs all on the disc, with no live services or add-ons. And ‚Äì perhaps most importantly ‚Äì Astro Bot puts fun front and centre. Together, it‚Äôs the sum of its parts and then some, the most complete package we‚Äôve had so far this generation. If you have a PS5, even if platformers aren‚Äôt your usual jam, I very much recommend you play it. 5/5

entry.title: Hideo Kojima: Connecting Worlds - inspirational but sanitised

link.title: Hideo Kojima: Connecting Worlds - inspirational but sanitised

entry.summary: It‚Äôs no secret that Hideo Kojima likes attention, and I‚Äôm sure he would have loved the idea of Connecting Worlds, a film that is ultimately part-documentary, part-marketing exercise. This is 100 percent modern Kojima, post-his fashionable makeover circa 2019. There are a lot of arty shots of him in empty offices and studios, and a compendium of clips of his famous friends complimenting him. But simultaneously, beneath the gushing praise from Geoff Keighley, Chvrches, and George Miller, there‚Äôs something purer on display. Seeing Kojima at work is to witness an inspirational passion for creation that I used to absorb through the pages of the gaming magazines I read growing up. In the 2020s, it serves as a reminder that video games are more than sales figures and Twitter arguments.

entry.title: Concord‚Äôs failure should be a wake-up call for the video game industry

link.title: Concord's failure should be a wake-up call for the video game industry

entry.summary: What a week it‚Äôs been in the video game industry! We‚Äôve witnessed one of the most remarkable failures ever, as Concord - the Firewalk Studios-developed live service game into which Sony had invested so much in the hope it would be the next big thing - was shut down after just two weeks in operation. Much of the criticism of the title was written off by its supporters and the press as ‚Äúhate‚Äù, but this story is actually a culmination of a number of factors that should not be swept under the carpet. If they are, then game developers and publishers might miss the important lessons that should be learnt from Concord‚Äôs demise.

entry.title: GTA IV‚Äôs Liberty City is still the best virtual city ever made

link.title: GTA IV's Liberty City is still the best virtual city ever made

entry.summary: In its review upon the game‚Äôs release in 2008, GamesRadar called Liberty City ‚Äúthe biggest reason to delve into GTA IV‚Äù. Its writers said it was ‚Äúeasily 100 times more detailed‚Äù than the map of its predecessor, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, concluding that altogether, the city was ‚Äúconvincingly like the real thing‚Äù. GTA IV tells story of Niko Bellic, but Liberty City has a life of its own It truly was like nothing we‚Äôd ever seen. Spanning three islands totalling just over six square miles, GTA IV‚Äôs map was nowhere near as expansive as the region depicted by Rockstar‚Äôs 2004 title, but it was perhaps the densest video game setting ever built in terms of population and detail - and certainly in character. For players focused on the story and the violence, many of the small touches that made Liberty City such a great virtual city probably passed by unnoticed. But even then, they undoubtedly felt that what they were playing was a premium product, even if they didn‚Äôt know why. My goal in this article is to pick apart those minutae that make GTA IV‚Äôs world such a compelling imitiation of a real-life city.

entry.title: Heartbound: An intriguing Early Access indie game about life itself

link.title: Heartbound: An intriguing Early Access indie game about life itself

entry.summary: How does your experience of a game change if you can listen to its developer talk for hours every day? That‚Äôs the rather unusual question presented by Heartbound, an Early Access game whose creator is also a streamer. But whether you‚Äôve caught Thor online or not, the indie game has plenty of intrigue to unpack in its own right. Heartbound has been a while in the making. The first version of the indie game was made available under Steam‚Äôs Early Access programme in December 2018, and its ironically-named developer Pirate Software - fronted by Jason Thor Hall - has been adding content as it‚Äôs become ready ever since. As of August 2024, the game currently consists of three of a planned five segments, one of which does not yet have an ending, and which take about three hours to play through altogether. Unusually, Thor streams his work on Twitch and YouTube, where he has a combined 3 million followers at the time of writing. There aren‚Äôt many games whose developers discuss their design philosophy online for hours every day, and it makes for a unique experience when playing the portion of the game that is currently available.

entry.title: Japan: Presence and attention to detail

link.title: Japan: Presence and attention to detail

entry.summary: A holiday brings a chance to unwind, time to focus on things beyond day-to-day life, and often an opportunity to take in another culture. Combined, these factors can produce a unique state of mind, and I find that one of the most difficult parts of any trip where it arises is to properly observe and harness the new perspective that brings before it disappears once again under the tide of work and life admin. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm working through the jet lag to type this out before the weekend is through. The trip itself ‚Äì another couple of weeks in Japan ‚Äì was fast-paced and thoroughly enjoyable. I spent my time between the bustle of Tokyo and more rural parts of Hokkaido, packing in as much good food and karaoke as possible along the way. But wherever I am in Japan, my eye is always drawn back to the attention to detail and earnestness ingrained in its culture. This is demonstrated in everything from an elaborate shop window display to consideration for others in public spaces. Following my last visit, I wrote about the hospitality and curiosity of those I met on my travels. My return served as something of a follow-up meditation session, and offered a chance to further concentrate and expand upon those thoughts, and properly consider what use they might be to me in my regular life.
